\chapter{Acrobat and PDFL SDK: JS 3D APIs}
\label{\detokenize{index:acrobat-and-pdfl-sdk-js-3d-apis}}\label{\detokenize{index::doc}}
To create 3D annotations and to attach scripts to them using this API, you need Adobe® Acrobat® Professional. Scripts attached to 3D annotations can run on Acrobat Pro Extended, Acrobat Pro, Acrobat Standard, and Adobe Reader® for Windows® and Mac OS® platforms. Unless otherwise noted, all JavaScript objects, properties, and methods have support starting in version 7.0.

The 3D JavaScript engine, which is distinct from the JavaScript engine for Acrobat, can be accessed in one of two ways. The primary way is by attaching a default script to the 3D annotation. This can be accomplished while placing a 3D annotation using the 3D Tool or on an existing 3D annotation by accessing its properties dialog box using the Select Object tool. This script will be run directly by the 3D JavaScript engine.

In addition, Acrobat provides a mechanism to directly access the entire 3D JavaScript engine API from within the Acrobat scripting engine by means of the JavaScript \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Annot3D.context3D}} property.

The following example illustrates how to access the 3D JavaScript engine. In this example, a button (or link) contains JavaScript code that rotates the U3D object named “Axes”.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{Get} \PYG{n}{index} \PYG{n}{of} \PYG{n}{page} \PYG{n}{containing} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{Annot3D} \PYG{n+nb}{object} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{count} \PYG{n}{starts} \PYG{n}{at} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}
 \PYG{n}{pageIndex} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{this}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pageNum}\PYG{p}{;}

 \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{Index} \PYG{n}{of} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{Annot3D} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{count} \PYG{n}{starts} \PYG{n}{at} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}
 \PYG{n}{annotIndex} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;}

 \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{Get} \PYG{n}{a} \PYG{n}{reference} \PYG{n}{to} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{Annot3D} \PYG{n}{script} \PYG{n}{context}\PYG{o}{.}
 \PYG{n}{c3d} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{this}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{getAnnots3D}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{pageIndex} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{[} \PYG{n}{annotIndex} \PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{context3D}\PYG{p}{;}

 \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{Get} \PYG{n}{a} \PYG{n}{reference} \PYG{n}{to} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{node} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{scene} \PYG{n}{named} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Axes}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{.}
 \PYG{n}{axes} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{c3d}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{scene}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{nodes}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{getByName}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Axes}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

 \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{Rotate} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n+nb}{object} \PYG{n}{about} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{X}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Axis} \PYG{n}{PI}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{6} \PYG{n}{radians} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{30} \PYG{n}{degrees}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}
 \PYG{n}{axes}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{transform}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{rotateAboutXInPlace}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{Math}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{PI} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{l+m+mi}{6} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

More extensive actions can be executed by having a button or link get the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SceneContext3d}} object and call a function defined in the default script of the 3D annotation, as in the following example.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{Get} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{Annot3D} \PYG{n}{script} \PYG{n}{context} \PYG{n}{of} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{targeted} \PYG{n}{annotation}\PYG{o}{.}
 \PYG{n}{context3D} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{getAnnots3D}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{context3D}\PYG{p}{;}

 \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{Call} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{JavaScript} \PYG{n}{function} \PYG{n}{setRenderMode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{defined} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{default}

   \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{script} \PYG{n}{of} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{referenced} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{n}{D} \PYG{n}{annotation}\PYG{o}{.}
 \PYG{n}{context3D}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{setRenderMode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{transparent}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The default script of the 3D annotation makes the definition.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{function} \PYG{n}{setRenderMode}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{renderModeName} \PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
     \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{var} \PYG{n}{i}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{scene}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{meshes}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{count}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{n}{i}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
         \PYG{n}{scene}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{meshes}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{getByIndex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{renderMode} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{renderModeName}\PYG{p}{;}
     \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
 \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Object overview}
\label{\detokenize{index:object-overview}}
This section provides an overview of the objects in the 3D JavaScript API.


\subsection{Basic objects}
\label{\detokenize{index:basic-objects}}
There are several basic objects, such as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Color}} , \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Matrix4x4}} , and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Vector3}} , that are used to create general\sphinxhyphen{}purpose objects. The basic objects are used throughout the API and are only meaningful when attached to objects such as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Scene}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Runtime}} . For example, you could create a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Color}} object and use it to set the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Background}} color of a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} .


\subsubsection{Vector3 Examples}
\label{\detokenize{index:vector3-examples}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{v1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{Vector3}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{4.5} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{n}{v2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{Vector3}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{13} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{n}{v3} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{Vector3}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\subsubsection{Color Examples}
\label{\detokenize{index:color-examples}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{c1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{Color}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.6}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.8}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{light} \PYG{n}{blue}

 \PYG{n}{c3} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{Color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{black}

 \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{A} \PYG{n}{function} \PYG{n}{to} \PYG{n}{blend} \PYG{n}{two} \PYG{n}{Colors}
 \PYG{n}{Color}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{prototype}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{blend} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{function}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{amount} \PYG{p}{)}

     \PYG{n}{red}       \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{this}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{r} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{p}{(} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{amount} \PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{color}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{r} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{amount} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Scene object}
\label{\detokenize{index:scene-object}}
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Scene}} is an object that contains all of the 3D\sphinxhyphen{}related content. It can be accessed using the global variable \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{scene}} , which is a reference to the main \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Scene}} object. Most of the contents of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Scene}} are structured into a hierarchy of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} objects, and maintains lists of all these objects in the form of a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SceneObjectList}} .

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_53181}{Scene}.


\subsection{Canvas object}
\label{\detokenize{index:canvas-object}}
Represents a rectangular region into which a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Scene}} is rendered from a particular viewpoint.

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_64381}{Canvas}.


\subsection{Runtime object}
\label{\detokenize{index:runtime-object}}
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Runtime}} object is used to represent the instance of the playback engine. It manages all event processing and places where the graphic and textual content is rendered. It is accessed via the global variable \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{runtime}} , which is a reference to the main \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Runtime}} object.

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_89312}{Runtime}.


\subsection{Console object}
\label{\detokenize{index:console-object}}
The Console is the Acrobat text output area. It is helpful in debugging scripts.


\subsection{Resource objects}
\label{\detokenize{index:resource-objects}}
Some objects, such as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Image}} , are driven by content that is streamed from a file or over a network. To create an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Image}} , load a .png, .jpg, or .gif file as a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Resource}} , which you may subsequently use to create a new \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Image}} object, as shown in the following example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{faceRes} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{Resource}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{pdf://picture.jpg}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{n}{faceImage} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{Image}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{faceRes} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{n}{aMaterial} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{scene}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{meshes}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{getByIndex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{material}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{n}{aMaterial}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{diffuseTexture}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{setImage}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{faceImage} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_90660}{Resource} and \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_33825}{Image}.


\subsection{Event handlers}
\label{\detokenize{index:event-handlers}}
There are several types of event handlers:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_44478}{CameraEventHandler}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_64405}{KeyEventHandler}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_88510}{MouseEventHandler}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_88392}{MenuEventHandler}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_90292}{RenderEventHandler}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_17926}{ScrollWheelEventHandler}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_72461}{SelectionEventHandler}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_37976}{TimeEventHandler}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_36913}{ToolEventHandler}

\end{itemize}

Each one responds to a different type of event during simulation. They use a callback mechanism to run a function when an event occurs. The event is passed as an argument to the event handler\textasciicircum{}s \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{onEvent}} function so that it can be queried when the function runs. Event handlers are registered via the \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_22923}{addEventHandler} method, of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Runtime}} object.


\subsection{CamaraEvent}
\label{\detokenize{index:camaraevent}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{CamaraEvent}} is created when a View is selected.

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_70741}{CameraEvent}.


\subsection{KeyEvent}
\label{\detokenize{index:keyevent}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{KeyEvent}} is created when a key is pressed or released while the 3D \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} is in focus. The following example illustrates how to handle a key event:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{myKeyHandler}          \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{KeyEventHandler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{n}{myKeyHandler}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{onEvent}  \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{function}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{event} \PYG{p}{)}
 \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
     \PYG{n}{console}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{print}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Key pressed with code: }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{characterCode} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
 \PYG{n}{runtime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{addEventHandler}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{myKeyHandler} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_34637}{KeyEvent}.


\subsection{MenuEvent}
\label{\detokenize{index:menuevent}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MenuEvent}} is created when a custom menu item is selected. To create a custom menu item on the context menu, invoke the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Runtime}} object\textasciicircum{}s \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{addCustomMenuItem}} method, which allows a script to be attached to the item selection event.

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_35098}{MenuEvent}.


\subsection{MouseEvent}
\label{\detokenize{index:mouseevent}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MouseEvent}} is created when the mouse is clicked on an active 3D \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} or the cursor moves over an active 3D \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} . The following syntax could be used to handle a mouse event:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{myMouseHandler}               \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{MouseEventHandler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{n}{myMouseHandler}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{onMouseDown}   \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{true}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{n}{myMouseHandler}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{target}        \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{scene}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{meshes}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{getByIndex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{n}{myMouseHandler}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{onEvent}       \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{function}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{event} \PYG{p}{)}
 \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
     \PYG{n}{console}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{print}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Mouse down at pixel }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{mouseX} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
     \PYG{n}{console}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{print}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{, }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{mouseY} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
 \PYG{n}{runtime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{addEventHandler}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{myMouseHandler} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_10766}{MouseEvent}.


\subsection{RenderEvent}
\label{\detokenize{index:renderevent}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RenderEvent}} is created immediately before an instance of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} is drawn. If there is a split view in Acrobat resulting in two visible 3D rendered areas, a unique \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RenderEvent}} will be called for each of them. This is necessary in the case of a camera\sphinxhyphen{}aligned image (sprite) in the 3D content that needs to be pixel\sphinxhyphen{}aligned. Since the pixel dimensions of the two areas are possibly different, there are two callbacks that pass the different dimensions. This makes it possible to modify the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Scene}} in the appropriate manner before it is drawn.

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_39788}{RenderEvent}.


\subsection{ScrollWheelEvent}
\label{\detokenize{index:scrollwheelevent}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ScrollWheelEvent}} object is created when the mouse scroll wheel is activated over an active 3D \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} object.

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_36231}{ScrollWheelEvent}.


\subsection{SelectionEvent}
\label{\detokenize{index:selectionevent}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SelectionEvent}} object is created when an object is selected from an active 3D \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} object or from a model tree. If the selection is made from a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} object, a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MouseEvent}} is also created.

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_25964}{SelectionEvent}.


\subsection{TimeEvent}
\label{\detokenize{index:timeevent}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{TimeEvent}} is created when the 3D annotation is enabled and simulation is active. The time and deltaTime properties are measured in terms of simulation time, not real time. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{TimeEvent}} objects are used to drive animation. If you need an accurate, real\sphinxhyphen{}time measurement, use the JavaScript \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Date}} object. The following syntax is used to handle a time event:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{myTimeHandler}              \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{TimeEventHandler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{n}{myTimeHandler}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{onEvent}      \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{function}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{event} \PYG{p}{)}
 \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
     \PYG{n}{console}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{print}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Current simulation time is:}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{time} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
     \PYG{n}{console}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{print}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{ second(s)}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
 \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
 \PYG{n}{runtime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{addEventHandler}\PYG{p}{(} \PYG{n}{myTimeHandler} \PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_41486}{TimeEvent}.


\subsection{ToolEvent}
\label{\detokenize{index:toolevent}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ToolEvent}} is created when a tool is clicked in the Acrobat 3D toolbar. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Runtime}} object\textasciicircum{}s \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{addCustomToolButton}} method allows you to add a custom tool to the toolbar which will also be generated, and allows a script to be attached to the tool selection event.

For more information, see \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_36004}{ToolEvent}.


\chapter{JavaScript Objects for Acrobat 3D}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:javascript-objects-for-acrobat-3d}}\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API::doc}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
A property labeled as R (read\sphinxhyphen{}only) is one whose value cannot be set. An object labeled as R (read\sphinxhyphen{}only) is one whose reference cannot be modified, though the object itself can be set and its properties may be modified. Unless otherwise indicated, all properties and objects labeled with R/W have read/write access.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Animation}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:animation}}
A type of \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_10063}{SceneObject}, used to store keyframe animation sequences of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} objects in the Scene. In addition to the methods and properties below, it also contains the same methods and properties as a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SceneObject}}.

\subsection{setColor}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:setcolor}}
Sets the background \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Color}}. If only one color is passed to this method, the background is a constant color. If two colors are passed to this method, the background is a linear gradient from top to bottom, with the first color argument representing the top color and the second representing the bottom color.

\section{Bone}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:bone}}
A type of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} used to modify the shape of a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Mesh}} , and is usually moved over time to create animated characters. It contains the same methods and properties as a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}}.

Related objects are \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_56757}{Node} and \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_30519}{Mesh}.

\section{Camera}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:camera}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} that controls the projection from world space to screen space. In addition to the methods and properties below, it also contains the same methods and properties as a \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_56757}{Node}.

\section{ClippingPlane}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:clippingplane}}
An object representing a plane, within the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Scene}} , that clips all geometry on one side of it. It is created by invoking the \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_59373}{createClippingPlane} method of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Scene}} object.

\section{Console}

\subsection{call}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:call}}
Calls into ActionScript with the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ExternalInterface}} calling convention to an exposed method (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ExternalInterface.addCallback}} in ActionScript). The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{call}} method returns the return value of the method specified as the first parameter.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
See the Acrobat JavaScript API Reference which has the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{callAS}} method of the AnnotRichMedia object that uses the same mechanism as the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{call}} method.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\subsection{gotoFrame}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:gotoframe}}
Activates the frame number specified by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{frameNumber}} in the current movie. If the data for a requested frame is not yet available, the player goes to the last frame available and stops, causing unexpected results during playback. Use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{percentLoaded}} property to determine if enough of the movie is available to execute the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gotoFrame()}} method. The argument \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{frameNumber}} is zero\sphinxhyphen{}based; that is, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{frameNumber}} is 0 in the first frame of the movie, 1 for the second frame, and so on. This differs from the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Goto}} action within Flash, which begins at 1.

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:syntax-23}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Syntax}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{gotoFrame}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{frameNumber}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:parameters-16}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Parameters}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:section-27}}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:returns-23}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Returns}

undefined

\subsection{pan}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:pan}}
This method pans a zoomed\sphinxhyphen{}in movie to the coordinates specified by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{x}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{y}}. Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mode}} to specify whether the values for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{x}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{y}} are pixels or a percentage of the window. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pan}} method does not pan beyond the boundaries of the zoomed\sphinxhyphen{}in movie.

\subsection{setZoomRect}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:setzoomrect}}
Zooms in on a rectangular area of the movie. The units of the coordinates are measured in twips (1440 units per inch).

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
To calculate the dimensions of a rectangle in the correct units, set the ruler units to Points and multiply the coordinates by 20 to get twips. (There are 72 points per inch.)
\end{sphinxadmonition}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:syntax-29}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Syntax}

\subsection{zoom}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:zoom}}
This method zooms the view by a relative scale factor specified by percentage. For example, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{zoom(50)}} doubles the size of the objects in the view, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{zoom(200}} ) reduces the size of objects in the view by one half, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{zoom(0)}} resets the view to 100\%. You cannot specify a scale factor that will zoom\sphinxhyphen{}out the original content further than 100\%.

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:syntax-31}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Syntax}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{zoom}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{percentage}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:parameters-20}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Parameters}

\section{Light}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:light}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} object that illuminates meshes in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Scene}}.

There are different types of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Light}} objects, each with their own distinct behavior. Infinite \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Light}} objects behave much like sunlight in that they cast parallel light in a given direction. Spot \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Light}} objects have a fixed cone angle that limits their beam to a conical projection. Point \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Light}} objects act similarly to a light bulb, where the light comes from a specific location in 3D space. Currently, none of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Light}} objects cast shadows.

In addition to the methods and properties that follow, the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Light}} object also contains the same methods and properties as a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}}.

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:properties-13}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Properties}


\section{Material}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:material}}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:properties-14}}

\subsection{rotateWithQuaternion}

\section{Mesh}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:mesh}}
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} object that contains geometry. A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Mesh}} object with no geometry has children \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} objects that can be transformed as a group. In addition to the methods and properties below, it contains the same methods and properties as a \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_56757}{Node}.

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:properties-17}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Properties}

\subsection{setColor}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:setcolor-1}}\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:id18}}
Acrobat 11

Sets the color, either for the entire mesh or for any one of the faces of the mesh. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{setColor}} can be called several time for the same mesh, either to change the color of the entire mesh or to change the color of the faces.

\section{MouseEvent}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:mouseevent}}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:properties-18}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Properties}


\section{MouseEventHandler}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:mouseeventhandler}}
An object that exposes a callback mechanism that allows a function to be evaluated when a mouse event occurs. The handler may be customized to filter out certain event types. Event handlers are registered with the Runtime \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_22923}{addEventHandler} method.

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:properties-19}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Properties}

\subsection{onEvent}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:onevent-4}}\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:id20}}

\section{Node}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:node}}
An object within the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Scene}} hierarchy (a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SceneObject}} ) that has a 3D representation. The following objects are considered \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} objects:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_53648}{Bone}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_61050}{Camera}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_68344}{ClippingPlane}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_86859}{Dummy}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_50414}{Light}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_30519}{Mesh}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_93289}{Procedural}

\end{itemize}

To obtain a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} object’s type, use the standard JavaScript \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{constructor}} property. For example, the following syntax prints the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} object’s type to the console:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{console}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{println}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{myNode}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{constructor}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

In addition to the methods and properties below, it contains the same methods and properties as a \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_10063}{SceneObject}.

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:properties-20}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Properties}


\subsection{detachFromCurrentAnimation}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:detachfromcurrentanimation}}
Removes the ability of the currently active \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Animation}} of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} object to transform the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}}.

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:syntax-71}}

\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:returns-72}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Returns}

undefined


\section{Procedural}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:procedural}}
Deprecated

A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Node}} object used to represent procedurally created geometry, such as constructive solid geometry (CSG) solids, procedural spheres, or NURB objects (a 3D curve or surface). A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Procedural}} object contains the same methods and properties as a \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_56757}{Node}.


\section{Quaternion}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:quaternion}}
Represents a rotation in 3D space, and allows for smooth interpolation (blending) between orientations of subjects. A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Quaternion}} is typically used for animating a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Camera}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Mesh}} over time, and can be converted to and from angles of rotation about the axes.


\subsection{Quaternion}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:quaternion-1}}\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:id21}}
A constructor that initializes the object with the identity matrix.

\section{RenderEvent}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:renderevent}}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:properties-21}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Properties}


\section{RenderEventHandler}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:rendereventhandler}}
An object that exposes a callback mechanism that allows a function to be evaluated when an event occurs. Event handlers are registered with the Runtime \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_22923}{addEventHandler} method. It issues a callback just before each \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} is rendered.


\subsection{RenderEventHandler}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:rendereventhandler-1}}\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:id24}}

\sphinxstylestrong{Returns}

A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RenderEventHandler}} object.

\section{Runtime}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:runtime}}
An object that represents the run\sphinxhyphen{}time instance of the player. Each \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Runtime}} object can have its own unique script engine and set of annotations. The variable \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{runtime}} is a global reference to this object.

\section{Scene}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:scene}}
An object that represents the hierarchy of the 3D related content, including \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Animation}} , \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Light}} , \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Material}} , and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Mesh}} objects. The variable \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{scene}} is a global reference to this object.

Related objects are \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_65932}{Animation}, \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_50414}{Light}, \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_19137}{Material} and \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_30519}{Mesh}.

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:properties-25}}
\sphinxstylestrong{Properties}

\section{SelectionEvent}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:selectionevent}}
(Acrobat 8.1) An object that is passed as an argument to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{onEvent}} method of the \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_72461}{SelectionEventHandler} object.

A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SelectionEvent}} object is created when an object is selected from an active 3D \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} object or from a model tree. If the selection is made from a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Canvas}} object, a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MouseEvent}} is also created.

\section{View}
\label{\detokenize{JS_3D_API:view}}
Acrobat 9.0

An object that represents a named view for the annotation.

See the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{viewCount}} property and the \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_27390}{getView} and \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_90335}{setView} methods of the \sphinxhref{JS\_3D\_API.html\#50552849\_89312}{Runtime} object.
